ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was so much more than I thought it would be-completely improved my creative writing skills and ability to be concise and descriptive at the same time.

Huge improvement on my writing: how to think about the purpose of my writing, my word choice, sentence structure. I really learned what questions to ask myself and what types of things to look for to produce the most effective writing.

I gained a large amount of respect and knowledge of many greats in the food writing canon, ranging from Julia Child to Anthony Bourdain. I further learned how to apply my language skills to the particular style of writing needed to address food without showering it in praise or unnecessary adjectives. Altogether, I learned quite a lot about a topic near and dear to my heart.
Writing, discussing food artfully, and writing about difficult subjects without appropriating.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I believe the readings were all geared to helping us succeed in our essays and allowing us to hear and discover different voices and styles that we could integrate into our writing

I loved the use of multiple media in the course and the variety of articles that we read-I think the class could have had some guest speakers or more discussion as opposed to just us sharing our blogs during class
Great assignments & great readings. Nothing felt like busy work.

This course is based primarily around four essays, as well as a supplementary food film festival and in-class seminar. The seminar was stellar, and I felt that discussion was able to proceed mostly without any awkward pauses, and Professor Stuart is a great moderator able to provide helpful feedback on her courses. The biggest single change I could make would be changing the grade cutoff for an A from a 95 to a 94: While Professor Stuart is a reasonable grader and her critiques of student works are generally valid, this high requirement put a bit of excess stress on myself and those I talked to. Also, the blogs, while short, kind of seemed like busy work (although she did do a good job of integrating them into discussions). Besides that, she is a genuinely kind individual that is both knowledgeable about the works she teaches and highly receptive to the interests of the class.
The writing instruction could be better, but the class discussions are great.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I enjoyed the workshops within breakout rooms and the collaborations-you could really tell that Prof. Stuart was trying to keep people engaged

Honestly, this course was pretty well calibrated to an online format, although I do miss out on the treats that I believe would normally be shared in person!  She was exceptionally flexible in this regard.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to other students. It is fun and if you like food, it will open you to ideas that invigorate you
Yes definitely! Take as a fun way to improve your writing and change your perspective about food and culture

If you are interested in food, yes. I loved every single second of this course even with all of the assignments, readings, and blog posts. It was all so rewarding and interesting because the topic was just fascinating, engaging, and exciting.

I would strongly recommend this course, but be warned that it is not a free fifth credit--it is an intensive English seminar with four highly edited essays that may prove difficult to students that do not really, really like food. That being said, Professor Stuart is a kind, intelligent teacher that was more flexible to times of COVID-19 than any other teacher, and she seemed aware at all times of our difficulties getting through the semester. Her flexibility in regards to our struggles made this course the only I truly looked forward to this semester, as it proved a welcome respite from my other courses being offered. Although this is not an easy A, if you share a true passion about food it is an excellent place for you to express it.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
